did.unittitle: Bonnie Franklin papers
did.abstract: Bonnie Franklin is best known for her role as Ann Romano on the television sitcom, One Day at a Time (1975-1984). The bulk of collection are bound scripts for television program, One Day at a Time. Additionally, there are a small number of photographs, posters, award nomination certificates, poster-like items, and ephemera.
did.physloc: Stored off-site. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: CONTAINS UNPROCESSED AUDIOVISUAL MATERIALS: Audiovisual materials are not currently available for access and will require further processing and assessment. If you have questions about this material please email AskLSC@library.ucla.edu.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use and Reproduction
userestrict.p: Property rights to the objects belong to UCLA Library Special Collections. All other rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Bonnie Franklin papers (Collection Number 2199). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Karie Jenkins, supervised by Julie Graham, 2015.

Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Problematic Content and Description in UCLA's library collections and archives.

bioghist.head: Biography/History
bioghist.p: Bonnie Gail Franklin was born January 6, 1944, in Santa Monica, CA. She attended Smith College, 1961-63 and earned a BA in English from University of California, Los Angeles, 1966. Franklin was a child tap-dancer and actress and a protégé of Donald O'Connor. She made her stage debut in San Francisco and an off-Broadway debut in in a production of Your Own Thing (1968). Among her stage appearances are Dames at Sea (1969), Applause (1970), Frankie and Johnny in the Clair de Lune (1988), and Annie Get Your Gun (1988), among others. Her film credits include The Kettles in the Ozarks (1956), The Wrong Man (1956), and A Summer Place (1959). She is best known for her role as Ann Romano on the television sitcom, One Day at a Time (1975-1984). Franklin received many awards and honors, among them a nomination from the Academy of Television Arts and Sciences for Outstanding Lead Actress in a Comedy Series (1982), One Day at a Time; Antoinette Perry Award nominee for Best Supporting Actress, Musical Applause, 1970; and Hollywood Foreign Press Golden Globe, for Best Performance by an Actress in a Television Series One Day at a Time, 1982 and 1983. Among her philanthropic activities, she was honorary chair for the National Committee of Arts with the Handicapped.
Bonnie Franklin died in Los Angeles on March 1, 2013.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of material related to the career of actress Bonnie Franklin. The bulk of collection are bound volumes of scripts for television program, One Day at a Time. Additionally, there are a small number of photographs, posters, award nomination certificates, poster-like items, and ephemera.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p:
Arranged in the following series:
Projects
Photographs
Awards and Honors
Ephemera

did.unittitle: Projects

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is arranged alphabetically by project title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This bulk of the series are bound scripts and clippings for the television program, One Day at a Time. Additionally there are a small number of poster-like items representing what appears to be stage performances.

Let's Tap videos (2 VHS tapes, 1 Betamax tape)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The includes images of Franklin, and a small number of images of Franklin with others such as Bob Barker, Carl Reiner, and Billy Crystal, Tim Conway, Valerie Bertinelli, and Robert Guillaume.

Awards and Honors

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p: There is no specific arrangement to the series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The series documents nominations from the Academy of Television Arts and Sciences for Outstanding Lead Actress in a Comedy Series; Antoinette Perry Award for Best Supporting Actress, Musical; and Hollywood Foreign Press Golden Globe, for Outstanding Achievement (One Day at a Time, 1982 and 1983). Also included is an Outer Critics Circle Award, watercolor painting presented to Franklin by the Association for Retarded Citizens, and a Domestic Relations Counseling Service of Indianapolis honor plaque.

did.unittitle: Award Nomination and Award Certificates

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: With Academy of Television Arts and Sciences Outstanding Lead Actress in a Comedy Series nomination; Antoinette Perry Award, Best Supporting Actress, Musical nomination; Hollywood Foreign Press, Golden Globe, Outstanding Achievement; Outer Critics Circle outstanding performance in Applause.

did.unittitle: Domestic Relations Counseling Service of Indianapolis honor plaque
Watercolor painting presented to Bonnie Franklin by the Association for Retarded Citizens
Ephemera

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The series consists of a wooden silhouette of a redheaded girl inscribed to Franklin, a Peanuts postcard and an Inner Circle program cover inscribed to Franklin.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p: There is no specific arrangement to the series.
